column2: Veteran Talking Machines by Brian Jewell [Softback] (0870692224-O)
column3:
"Veteran Talking Machines" by Brian Jewell is a captivating and informative book that explores the golden age of early sound reproduction, focusing on the mechanical talking machines that brought music and the spoken word into homes long before the advent of radio and digital technology. Originally published in the 1970s, the book is both a historical survey and a collector‚Äôs guide, rich with photographs, period advertisements, and insightful commentary.

üìª Overview

Jewell presents a comprehensive look at phonographs and gramophones from the late 19th and early 20th centuries, detailing the development, design, and cultural significance of these pioneering machines. He offers readers a journey through the evolution of the talking machine, from Edison's early tinfoil phonographs to the elegant and highly collectible Victrolas and gramophones of the 1920s.

üõ†Ô∏è Key Features

  • Historical Narrative: Traces the key milestones in the development of talking machines, including the work of innovators like Thomas Edison, Emile Berliner, and Eldridge Johnson.

  • Manufacturer Profiles: Covers notable makers from both the United States and Europe, such as Victor, Columbia, HMV, and Path√©.

  • Visual Documentation: Lavishly illustrated with black-and-white and color photographs of machines, labels, horn styles, and cabinet designs, offering a visual feast for collectors and history buffs.

  • Collector Guidance: Includes practical advice on collecting, identifying, and caring for vintage phonographs and gramophones, with special attention to detail and authenticity.

  • Cultural Insights: Explores how talking machines shaped entertainment, social life, and the music industry in the early 20th century.

üìù Style and Appeal

Jewell‚Äôs writing is clear, engaging, and informative, appealing to both newcomers and seasoned collectors. His deep appreciation for the artistry and engineering of these machines shines through, making the book not only a useful reference but also a nostalgic celebration of an era when music came to life through winding handles, spinning discs, and beautifully crafted cabinetry.

"Veteran Talking Machines" remains a cherished volume for enthusiasts of vintage audio, antique technology, and the history of recorded sound. Whether you're a collector, historian, or simply fascinated by the early days of home entertainment, this book offers a rich and rewarding experience.

Dimensions

  • Length: 7 1/2"
  • Width: 8"¬†
  • Thickness: 3/8"
  • Condition: Good

column2: Music Appreciation with the Victrola for Children [Hardback] (PS6997-O)
column3:
"Music Appreciation with the Victrola for Children" is an early 20th-century educational guide designed to introduce young learners to the world of classical music through the use of the Victrola phonograph. Published by the Victor Talking Machine Company, the book was part of a broader effort to integrate recorded music into schools and homes, fostering a love for music and cultural literacy from an early age.

üìö Overview

The book provides a structured curriculum for teaching music appreciation to children, using Victor recordings as a central tool. Aimed at educators and parents, it outlines lesson plans, listening activities, and discussions to engage students in both the technical and emotional aspects of music.

üé∂ Key Features

  • Curated Listening Selections: The book suggests specific pieces from the Victor catalog, including works by Beethoven, Mozart, Tchaikovsky, and other classical composers, carefully chosen for their appeal and educational value for young ears.

  • Child-Friendly Explanations: Musical concepts‚Äîsuch as melody, rhythm, instrumentation, and form‚Äîare introduced in simple, age-appropriate language.

  • Integrated Activities: Includes singing, storytelling, drawing, and movement exercises tied to the music, encouraging multisensory engagement.

  • Historical and Cultural Context: Offers brief backgrounds on composers and pieces to help children understand the music‚Äôs origins and meaning.

  • Moral and Aesthetic Development: Reflecting the values of its time, the book also emphasizes how exposure to great music can cultivate taste, discipline, and character.

üìù Style and Legacy

Written in a warm, instructive tone, Music Appreciation with the Victrola for Children represents an important moment in the history of music education and sound recording. It illustrates how early 20th-century educators embraced new technology to enrich the classroom and democratize access to fine art.

Today, it‚Äôs a charming historical artifact for collectors, music educators, and Victrola enthusiasts, capturing a time when the phonograph was a marvel‚Äîand when children across the country first heard the symphony in their own homes and schools.

Dimensions

  • Length: 8"
  • Width: ¬†5 1/2"
  • Thickness: 1"
  • Condition: Very Good

column2: The Victor Book of the Opera [2nd Edition] [Hardback] (PS6998-2-O)
column3:
"The Victor Book of the Opera" is a classic reference guide and companion for opera enthusiasts, originally published by the Victor Talking Machine Company. First released in the early 20th century and frequently updated in later editions, the book offers accessible yet authoritative summaries of the world's most beloved operas, enriched by historical context and musical insights.

üé≠ Overview

Designed to accompany Victor‚Äôs phonograph recordings of operatic works, the book presents detailed synopses of major operas, including those by Mozart, Verdi, Wagner, Puccini, Bizet, Rossini, and many others. It covers the plot, principal characters, key arias, and musical highlights of each opera, making it an indispensable tool for both newcomers and seasoned opera lovers.

üìö Contents & Features

  • Opera Summaries: Clear, scene-by-scene breakdowns of plots with commentary on dramatic and musical elements.

  • Composer Biographies: Brief sketches of each composer's life and contributions to the operatic tradition.

  • Historical Context: Notes on the premieres, critical reception, and evolution of each opera's performance history.

  • Illustrations: Many editions include portraits of composers, photos of performers, and promotional materials from the Victor archives.

  • Index of Artists and Recordings: Cross-references to Victor's catalog, helping collectors and listeners find relevant recordings on shellac or vinyl.

üìù Style and Legacy

Written in an inviting, sometimes florid early 20th-century style, The Victor Book of the Opera reflects the golden age of both opera and phonograph culture. As much a marketing tool as a scholarly work, it celebrated the synergy between recorded music and live performance, and introduced countless listeners to the joys of opera through their Victrolas.

Even today, it remains a beloved collectible and historical document‚Äîa time capsule of operatic enthusiasm, industry pride, and musical artistry from the dawn of recorded sound.

Dimensions

  • Length: 8 1/4"
  • Width: 6 1/4"
  • Thickness: 1 1/8"
  • Condition: Good

column2: From Tin Foil to Stereo by Oliver Read & Walter L. Welch [Softback] (0672212056-O)
column3:
"From Tin Foil to Stereo: Evolution of the Phonograph" by Oliver Read and Walter L. Welch is a comprehensive and authoritative history of sound recording, tracing the technological and cultural development of the phonograph from its earliest days to the mid-20th century.

üìñ Overview

The book begins with Thomas Edison's invention of the phonograph in 1877, a device that could record and reproduce sound using tinfoil-covered cylinders. From there, it covers the key figures, innovations, and companies that shaped the sound recording industry, including Alexander Graham Bell, Emile Berliner, Eldridge R. Johnson, and Guglielmo Marconi, as well as major corporations like Victor, Columbia, and RCA.

üéº Key Themes & Topics

  • Technical Advancements: The shift from tinfoil to wax cylinders, shellac discs, and ultimately to vinyl LPs and stereo sound.

  • Industry Evolution: The rise of the recording industry, format wars, and how the phonograph changed the way people experienced music.

  • Cultural Impact: The influence of the phonograph on popular music, broadcasting, and the broader entertainment landscape.

  • Collector‚Äôs Insight: Includes details on early machines, rare recordings, and historic advertisements, making it a favorite among vintage audio and phonograph enthusiasts.

üìù Style and Features

Richly illustrated with photographs, diagrams, and vintage ephemera, From Tin Foil to Stereo blends technical detail with engaging storytelling, making it both a valuable reference and an enjoyable read. The authors' deep knowledge and passion for the subject shine through, offering readers both historical accuracy and a nostalgic glimpse into the golden age of analog sound.

Dimensions:

  • Length: 5 1/4"
  • Width: 8 1/4"
  • Thickness: 1 1/4"

column2: Tuck's Gramophone Record Post Card When Johnnie Comes Marching Home (8491-20-O)
column3:
Tuck's gramophone record postcards are a charming fusion of nostalgia and creativity, capturing the spirit of the early 20th century. These unique collectibles feature a small, playable record embedded into a postcard format, allowing recipients to enjoy a snippet of music or a spoken message along with the visual art. The postcards often showcase intricate designs and vibrant colors, reflecting the era's artistic styles, from Art Nouveau to early modernism.

Each Tuck's postcard typically includes a delightful illustration on one side, while the other side is reserved for a personalized message and postage details. This innovative approach not only transformed the way people communicated but also offered a glimpse into the cultural trends of the time. Whether as a musical greeting or a decorative keepsake, Tuck's gramophone record postcards serve as a whimsical reminder of a bygone era when sending a note could also mean sharing a tune.

Dimensions

  • Length: 5 1/2"
  • Width: 3 1/2"
  • Postcard Number: 8491
  • Postcard Title: Regimental Badges and Their Wearers
  • Song Number: 20
  • Song Title: When Johnnie Comes Marching Home

column2: The Illustrated history of Phonographs by Daniel Marty - Hardback
column3:
The Illustrated History of Phonographs by Daniel Marty is a visually stunning and thoroughly engaging exploration of the evolution of phonograph technology from its inception to its modern-day significance. This beautifully illustrated book takes readers on a journey through the rich history of phonographs, featuring a wealth of detailed images, including historical photographs, advertisements, and technical schematics.

Daniel Marty delves into the development of phonograph technology, tracing its origins from Thomas Edison‚Äôs groundbreaking tinfoil phonograph to the sophisticated devices of the 20th century. The book covers key milestones, influential inventors, and the impact of phonographs on music, culture, and society. Each chapter highlights significant advancements and provides context about how these innovations transformed the way we experience sound.

With its combination of historical narrative and vivid illustrations, The Illustrated History of Phonographs offers both a comprehensive overview and a visual feast for enthusiasts and scholars alike. It's an essential addition to the library of anyone interested in the history of audio technology and the legacy of the phonograph.

Dimensions

  • Length: 12"
  • Width: 10 1/2"
  • Thickness: 1"
  • Jacket: Yes
  • Condition: Good

column2: The Bluebird Discography Volume 1 18000, B-4900. B-5000 & B-6000 Series by John R. Bolig
column3:
The Bluebird Discography Volume 1 by John Bolig is an authoritative and meticulously compiled reference work that dives deep into the catalog of one of the most influential labels in early jazz and blues history. This first volume of Bolig‚Äôs comprehensive discography series covers the essential recordings made by Bluebird Records, a key player in the American music scene during the 1930s and 1940s.

Bolig‚Äôs detailed analysis includes an extensive listing of Bluebird's 78 rpm releases, complete with recording dates, artist information, and catalog numbers. The book offers invaluable insights into the artists and sessions that defined the label's legacy, featuring in-depth notes on notable performers and the impact of their recordings on the development of jazz, blues, and popular music.

The Bluebird Discography Volume 1 is not just a catalog but a deep dive into the historical context and significance of the recordings, making it an essential resource for music historians, collectors, and enthusiasts. Bolig's expertise and dedication to the subject provide readers with a thorough understanding of Bluebird's pivotal role in the evolution of recorded music.

Dimensions

  • Length: 10"
  • Width: 7:
  • Thickness: 1"
  • Condition: Excellent

column2: From Tinfoil to Stereo - The Acoustic Years of the Recording Industry 1877-1929 by Welch & Burt
column3:
From Tinfoil to Stereo: The Acoustic Years of the Recording Industry 1877-1929 offers a captivating journey through the formative years of recorded sound. This meticulously researched exploration delves into the pioneering days of the recording industry, tracing the evolution from Thomas Edison's early tinfoil phonograph to the sophisticated acoustic recording techniques that laid the groundwork for modern audio. The book paints a vivid picture of the technical innovations, social impacts, and cultural shifts that shaped the industry during this transformative period.

With a rich array of historical anecdotes, detailed analyses of recording technologies, and profiles of influential figures, From Tinfoil to Stereo brings to life the struggles and triumphs of early sound recording. Readers will discover how these early experiments in capturing and reproducing sound influenced music, entertainment, and media, setting the stage for the eventual leap to electric recording and stereo sound. Perfect for history buffs, music enthusiasts, and anyone interested in the roots of our audio-visual culture, this book offers a comprehensive and engaging look at the acoustic era of the recording industry.

column2: Victrola Record The Collector's Guide to Victor Records by Micheal W. Sherman
column3:
Victrola Record: The Collector's Guide to Victor Records by Michael W. Sherman is an essential reference for enthusiasts, collectors, and historians interested in the rich legacy of Victor Records. This comprehensive guide provides detailed information on one of the most influential record labels in the history of recorded sound.

Key features of the book include:

  • In-Depth Catalog: Sherman offers an extensive catalog of Victor Records, including detailed entries on a wide range of recordings produced by the label. The book covers various catalog numbers, titles, artists, and release dates, making it a valuable resource for identifying and cataloging Victor records.
  • Historical Context: The guide situates Victor Records within the broader context of the recording industry, exploring the company‚Äôs role in shaping early 20th-century sound recording. It provides insight into the technological and commercial aspects of Victor Records and their impact on the development of the phonograph.
  • Collector‚Äôs Insights: The book provides practical advice for collectors, including tips on identifying, evaluating, and preserving Victor Records. Sherman‚Äôs guidance helps collectors understand the nuances of Victor‚Äôs catalog and the factors that affect the value and condition of these historical recordings.
  • Visual Documentation: Victrola Record is richly illustrated with images of record labels, album covers, and promotional materials. These visual elements enhance the book‚Äôs utility by helping collectors recognize different issues and editions of Victor Records.
  • Detailed Appendices: The guide includes appendices with additional resources, such as cross-references to related publications and information on Victor‚Äôs recording sessions. These appendices add depth to the book‚Äôs coverage and support further research and exploration.

Victrola Record: The Collector's Guide to Victor Records is renowned for its thorough research and practical approach, making it an indispensable resource for anyone interested in the history of Victor Records and the broader world of early sound recordings.

column2: Phono-Graphics The Visual Paraphernalia of the Talking Machine by Arnold Schwartzman
column3:
Phono-Graphics: The Visual Paraphernalia of the Talking Machine by Arnold Schwartzman is a visually stunning and meticulously curated exploration of the art and design associated with early phonograph advertising and packaging. This book delves into the rich visual history of the talking machine era, showcasing the creative and often elaborate graphic elements used to market and promote phonographs and records.

Key features of the book include:

  • Visual Archive: Schwartzman presents a comprehensive collection of imagery related to early phonographs, including advertisements, posters, record labels, and promotional materials. The book is richly illustrated with high-quality reproductions of these artifacts, offering a vivid snapshot of the visual culture surrounding the talking machine industry.
  • Historical Context: The book provides insight into how these visual elements were used to attract and engage consumers during the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Schwartzman explores the role of graphic design in shaping public perceptions of phonographs and records, highlighting the intersection of art, technology, and commerce.
  • Artistic Analysis: Schwartzman‚Äôs analysis includes discussions of design trends, stylistic influences, and the impact of these visual materials on the branding and marketing of phonographs. The book examines how graphic design evolved alongside technological advancements in sound recording.
  • Collector‚Äôs Perspective: For collectors and enthusiasts, Phono-Graphics offers a valuable resource for understanding the aesthetic and historical significance of phonograph-related visual materials. It provides context for appreciating the artistic and cultural value of these early marketing tools.
  • Educational Resource: The book serves as an educational resource for those interested in the history of graphic design and advertising. It provides a comprehensive overview of how visual design contributed to the development and popularization of early sound recording technology.

Phono-Graphics: The Visual Paraphernalia of the Talking Machine is celebrated for its exceptional visual presentation and thoughtful analysis, making it an essential addition to the libraries of those interested in the history of sound recording and the evolution of graphic design.

column2: Edison Amberol Cylinders U.S. and Foreign Issues 1908-1913 by Allan Sutton
column3:
Edison Amberol Cylinders: U.S. and Foreign Issues 1908-1913 by Allan Sutton is an authoritative reference guide that focuses on the Edison Amberol cylinders produced during a pivotal period from 1908 to 1913. This book is an invaluable resource for collectors, historians, and enthusiasts of early sound recording technology.

Key features of the book include:

  • Thorough Catalog: Sutton provides an extensive catalog of Edison Amberol cylinders from the specified period, documenting both U.S. and foreign issues. Each entry includes detailed information such as catalog numbers, titles, artists, and release dates, offering a comprehensive look at the cylinders produced during these years.
  • Historical Insight: The book explores the historical context of the Edison Amberol cylinders, including their development, technological advancements, and their role in the broader landscape of early sound recording. Sutton places these cylinders within the context of Edison‚Äôs innovations and the evolution of the phonograph industry.
  • Visual Documentation: Richly illustrated with photographs of cylinders, labels, and promotional materials, the book provides visual references that help readers understand the design and branding of the Amberol cylinders. This visual documentation is crucial for collectors and enthusiasts seeking to identify and appreciate these historical artifacts.
  • Technical Details: Sutton includes technical information on the construction and playback of Amberol cylinders, including insights into their sound quality and the phonographs designed to play them. This information is valuable for understanding the technical aspects of the cylinders and their impact on the recording industry.
  • Collector‚Äôs Guide: For collectors, the book offers practical guidance on identifying, valuing, and preserving Edison Amberol cylinders. It includes tips on recognizing different issues and variations, making it a useful tool for anyone involved in the collection and study of these early recordings.

Edison Amberol Cylinders: U.S. and Foreign Issues 1908-1913 is celebrated for its meticulous research and detailed presentation, making it an essential resource for anyone interested in the history and preservation of Edison‚Äôs influential sound recordings.

column3:
Edison: Inventing the Century by Neil Baldwin offers a captivating and comprehensive biography of Thomas Edison, one of history's most prolific inventors. This book delves into Edison's life, exploring not only his numerous groundbreaking inventions but also the personal and professional experiences that shaped his career and legacy.

Key features of the book include:

  • Detailed Biography: Baldwin provides an in-depth look at Edison‚Äôs life, from his early years and formative experiences to his rise as a leading inventor and businessman. The book covers his development of key inventions such as the phonograph, the incandescent light bulb, and the motion picture camera.
  • Innovative Contributions: The narrative emphasizes Edison‚Äôs significant contributions to technology and industry. It explores his role in shaping modern life through his innovations and his impact on various fields, including electricity, sound recording, and film.
  • Personal Insights: The book delves into Edison's personal life, including his family relationships, his work ethic, and his complex personality. Baldwin paints a nuanced portrait of Edison, highlighting both his remarkable achievements and his human flaws.
  • Historical Context: Baldwin situates Edison‚Äôs work within the broader historical and cultural context of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The book provides insight into the technological and societal changes of the era and how Edison‚Äôs inventions influenced these developments.

column3:
Directory of American Disc Record Brands and Manufacturers 1891-1943 by Allan Sutton is a definitive reference work that meticulously catalogs the myriad brands and manufacturers of American disc records from the late 19th century through the early 20th century. This comprehensive guide covers a critical period in the history of recorded sound, offering a detailed look at the evolution of the disc record industry.

Key features of the book include:

  • Extensive Listings: Sutton provides an exhaustive directory of disc record brands and manufacturers, including both well-known and obscure names. Each entry typically includes information on the brand‚Äôs history, notable records, and the companies that produced them.
  • Historical Context: The book situates each brand within the broader context of the recording industry's development. It offers insights into how various manufacturers influenced and were influenced by technological advances and market trends.
  • Illustrations and Documentation: The guide includes illustrations of record labels, advertisements, and promotional materials that help to visually represent the brands and their products. This visual documentation aids in understanding the branding and marketing strategies of the time.

column2: Thomas A. Edison's Menlo Park Including The Sarah Jordan Boarding House
column3:
Thomas A. Edison's Menlo Park Laboratory is a detailed account of the innovative work and historical significance of Thomas Edison‚Äôs famous laboratory located in Menlo Park, New Jersey. The book highlights Edison‚Äôs groundbreaking experiments and inventions during the late 19th century, which included the development of the phonograph and the early practical electric light bulb. It provides a vivid portrayal of Edison's inventive genius and the collaborative atmosphere that fostered many of his successes.

A notable aspect of the book is its depiction of the Sarah Jordan Boarding House, which played a crucial role in the daily lives of Edison and his team. This boarding house, operated by Sarah Jordan, was where many of Edison‚Äôs employees stayed while working at the Menlo Park Laboratory. The boarding house was not only a place for rest but also a hub of social and professional interaction. It provided a supportive environment for the inventors, facilitating the close-knit relationships that were integral to the collaborative spirit of the laboratory.

Overall, the book offers a comprehensive look at Edison's laboratory and the surrounding community, showcasing how both contributed to the era‚Äôs technological advancements.

column2: Edison Diamond Disc Record
column3:
Edison Diamond Disc Record

Thomas Edison introduced the Diamond Disc record in 1912 as means to compete with the success of 78 RPM records (laterally recorded). These records require an Edison Diamond Disc machine or an adapter to play vertically recorded records.

  • Title / Performer:
    • Track A - Ameriaca (My Country 'tis of Thee) / Mixed Quartet (Metropolitain Quartet)
    • Track B - The Star-Spangled Banner / Baritone and Chorus (Thomas Chalmers)
  • Date Recorded - 04 or 05/1914
  • Take - C
  • Label Style - Etched
  • Condition - OW
  • Playback Speed - 80 RPMs
  • Recording Method - Vertical

Condition Notes:

The Phonograph Shop only sells quality and playable records, for this reason we do not use standard grading models. We do not sell records with thousands of scratches, needle drops, chips, cracks or that have turned grey from excessive play, with the exception of¬†Ah, Man! (see grading chart below).¬† We also reuse pictures for efficiency when listing duplicate items, so you may not receive the one pictured, but it will be of the same grade. Please keep in mind that record grading is somewhat subjective and requires experience. All record grading decisions are at the discretion of The Phonograph Shop. We will not debate nuances in personal opinions or other grading systems. If you are a serious collector and feel our grading may be at odds with yours, please reach out before ordering. The following describes our grading.

Grading Scale:

  • Holy Grail (HG): Extremely rare, but records that are cosmetically perfect.
  • Oh, Wow (OW): Record is in a condition that anyone should love to add it to their collection.¬†¬†
  • Desirable (DE): These records retain most of their original glossy appearance but may contain a few light scratches.
  • Daily Player (DP): These records are very playable but may contain more than a few light scratches.
  • Ah, Man! (AM): These records are not good playing records. The only time we will offer this grade of record is if it is historically important or considered extremally rare. Example: Blind Lemon Jefferson with grooves so worn it is unrecognizable when played.

Shipping:

  • Records will be shipped in a 12" x 12" x 4" box
  • Layered between cardboard protectors
  • Surrounded by peanuts or wadded paper.
  • Media mail (unless you order non record items
column5: Media > Music & Sound Recordings > Records & LPs

Installation Tip: These may need to be swedged into place, depending on the size of your crank hole. This can be achieved by dimpling the inside or by using an object slightly larger than the inside diameter (such as a 13mm socket) and tapping it into the ferrule once placed in the cabinet. The Phonograph Shop uses a ring sizer from the jewelry industry because it is tapered and pushes the inside of the ferrule to the inside diameter of the crank hole.

column2: Victor Turntable Felt Precut 8" Dark Green (503DGN)
column3:
Victor Turntable Felt Precut 8" Dark Green for:

VIC-E, M, R, Z

Others

This product works on other manufacturers machines as well. Measure the diameter of your turntable. Any turntable measuring¬†6 7/8"¬†with a traditional 1/4" spindle will be suitable for installation.

Dimensions

Diameter - 8" (Actual Diameter 7 15/16")
Thickness - 1/16"
Diameter Center Hole - 5/16"
Color Preference - Dark Green

Installation Instructions:

The Phonograph Shop uses White "Elmers" Glue for installation. Spray adhesive is also a good choice. If using spray adhesive, you may want to tape the edge of the turntable to protect the plated finish and avoid clean up later.

  1. Remove Old Felt - Using a wire brush or other tool scrape off the old felt. Take care to avoid the plated sides of the turntable. Another option is to soak the turntable in warm water.
  2. Clean The Turntable - Using '0000' steel wool or light cleaning pad remove all of the remaining glue, rust and grime. Goof-off is a good cleaner for the glue, but soap works well. This is your opportunity to really make your turntable shine!
  3. Dry Thoroughly
  4. Apply Glue: Using a paper towel, spread an even, thin layer of glue across the entire surface of the turntable. It does not require much. Just enough to do the job. Take precautions on the edge, as to not allow it to run down the side.
  5. Place the Felt: Using a pencil or ink pen as a guide in the center hole, align the felt on the turntable, adjust as needed.
  6. Clean Up - If required use a damp paper towel to remove any overflow along the edge.
  7. Let Dry - Once satisfied with placement and clean up, flip the turn table over (felt side down) and place on a clean, flat surface for 15 - 30 minutes or according to your glue's curing time.
column5: Arts & Entertainment > Hobbies & Creative Arts > Arts & Crafts > Art & Crafting Tools > Felting Pads & Mats

column2: Victor Turntable Felt Precut 10" Dark Brown (9675DBN)
column3:
Victor Turntable Felt Precut 10" Dark Brown for:

V-0, 1, 2, 3, 4

VV-IV, VI, VIII

Others

This product works on other manufacturers machines as well. Measure the diameter of your turntable. Anything between 9 7/8" - 9 13/16" with a traditional 1/4" spindle will be suitable for installation.

Dimensions

Diameter - 10" (Actual Diameter 9 13/16")
Thickness - 1/16"
Diameter Center Hole - 5/16"
Color Preference - Dark¬†Brown

Installation Instructions:

The Phonograph Shop uses White "Elmers" Glue for installation. Spray adhesive is also a good choice. If using spray adhesive, you may want to tape the edge of the turntable to protect the plated finish and avoid clean up later.

  1. Remove Old Felt - Using a wire brush or other tool scrape off the old felt. Take care to avoid the plated sides of the turntable. Another option is to soak the turntable in warm water.
  2. Clean The Turntable - Using '0000' steel wool or light cleaning pad remove all of the remaining glue, rust and grime. Goof-off is a good cleaner for the glue, but soap works well. This is your opportunity to really make your turntable shine!
  3. Dry Thoroughly
  4. Apply Glue: Using a paper towel, spread an even, thin layer of glue across the entire surface of the turntable. It does not require much. Just enough to do the job. Take precautions on the edge, as to not allow it to run down the side.
  5. Place the Felt: Using a pencil or ink pen as a guide in the center hole, align the felt on the turntable, adjust as needed.
  6. Clean Up - If required use a damp paper towel to remove any overflow along the edge.
  7. Let Dry - Once satisfied with placement and clean up, flip the turn table over (felt side down) and place on a clean, flat surface for 15 - 30 minutes or according to your glue's curing time.

column2: Instructions for the Victrola VV-X Type J (PDF Version)
column3:
Instructions for the Victrola VV-XI Type G (PDF Version)

Number of Pages: 19

This is a professional scan of the complete, original document.¬† The scan has been cleansed of all blemishes.

The Phonograph Shop¬†uses a museum quality book scanner to create our Archives. We take pride in offering the best quality digital files available. We also edit the files to remove any stained, ripped¬†or damaged areas.

Our hope is to eventually create a repository of all phonographs, talking machines, and related material. We charge a nominal fee to cover the costs of storage (size and complexity of the file), equipment and acquiring new content for the archives. Our time is donated to the development of the Archives.

We gladly accept donations of loaned materials.¬† This material will be added to the archive and the originals returned to their owners. Please contact us if you are interested in helping.

You will be sent a link to download the searchable PDF file once you complete your order. If you experience any issues, please to not hesitate to contact¬†The Phonograph Shop¬†directly,

Note: We have added The Phonograph Shop Archive logo to the file.

column2: Edison Blue Amberol Recordings 1912-1914 by Ronald Dethlefson - Paperback
column3:
Edison Blue Amberol Recordings 1912-1914 by Ronald Dethlefson is a definitive reference work that meticulously documents the influential recordings produced by Edison Records during a pivotal period in early sound recording history. This comprehensive volume focuses on the Blue Amberol cylinders, which represent a significant technological advancement in audio recording and playback.

Dethlefson offers an in-depth examination of the Blue Amberol format, known for its improved sound quality and durability compared to its predecessors. The book provides detailed listings of recordings from 1912 to 1914, including information on artists, track titles, and catalog numbers. Additionally, Dethlefson includes historical context and insights into the recording sessions, offering readers a deeper understanding of the era's music and the role of Edison Records in shaping the recording industry.

Edison Blue Amberol Recordings 1912-1914 is an invaluable resource for collectors, historians, and enthusiasts of early 20th-century music and technology. Its thorough research and extensive data make it an essential tool for those interested in exploring the legacy of Edison‚Äôs Blue Amberol cylinders and their impact on the development of recorded sound.

column2: Look for the Dog by Robert W Baumbach - Hardback
column3:
Look for the Dog: An Illustrated Guide to Victor Talking Machines by Robert Baumbach is a comprehensive and richly illustrated reference book focused on the history and technology of Victor Talking Machines, a prominent brand of early phonographs. The book serves as both a historical document and a collector's guide, offering detailed insights into the various models of Victor phonographs and their place in the evolution of sound recording.

The title "Look for the Dog" refers to the iconic trademark of Victor Talking Machines, which features a depiction of a dog listening to a phonograph, symbolizing the company's commitment to high-quality sound reproduction.

Key features of the book include:

  • Illustrations and Photographs: The guide is notable for its extensive collection of illustrations and photographs that showcase different models of Victor phonographs, their components, and various advertisements from the early 20th century.
  • Historical Context: Baumbach provides background on the development of Victor Talking Machines, including their impact on the recording industry and their technological innovations.
  • Collector's Information: The book includes details on the identification, valuation, and restoration of Victor phonographs, making it a valuable resource for collectors and enthusiasts.
  • Technical Details: It covers the technical aspects of the machines, including their mechanisms and design features, offering a deeper understanding of how they functioned.

Look for the Dog is an essential resource for anyone interested in the history of sound recording, vintage technology, or the specific legacy of Victor Talking Machines.

column2: Mohawk Scratch-Off Mahogany (13 oz)
column3:
Use this on a machine that already has a good, clean finish to help hide imperfections. Very lightly tinted.

Thoroughly clean all surfaces and apply with a lent free cotton cloth. Allow to dry and buff with a clean cotton cloth.

column2: Victor Turntable Felt Precut 10" Light Green (393LGN)
column3:
Victor Turntable Felt Precut 10" Light Green for:

V-0, 1, 2, 3, 4

VV-IV, VI, VIII

Others

This product works on other manufacturers machines as well. Measure the diameter of your turntable. Anything between 9 7/8" - 9 13/16" with a traditional 1/4" spindle will be suitable for installation.

Dimensions

Diameter - 10" (Actual Diameter 9 13/16")
Thickness - 1/16"
Diameter Center Hole - 5/16"
Color Preference - Light Green

Installation Instructions:

The Phonograph Shop uses White "Elmers" Glue for installation. Spray adhesive is also a good choice. If using spray adhesive, you may want to tape the edge of the turntable to protect the plated finish and avoid clean up later.

  1. Remove Old Felt - Using a wire brush or other tool scrape off the old felt. Take care to avoid the plated sides of the turntable. Another option is to soak the turntable in warm water.
  2. Clean The Turntable - Using '0000' steel wool or light cleaning pad remove all of the remaining glue, rust and grime. Goof-off is a good cleaner for the glue, but soap works well. This is your opportunity to really make your turntable shine!
  3. Dry Thoroughly
  4. Apply Glue: Using a paper towel, spread an even, thin layer of glue across the entire surface of the turntable. It does not require much. Just enough to do the job. Take precautions on the edge, as to not allow it to run down the side.
  5. Place the Felt: Using a pencil or ink pen as a guide in the center hole, align the felt on the turntable, adjust as needed.
  6. Clean Up - If required use a damp paper towel to remove any overflow along the edge.
  7. Let Dry - Once satisfied with placement and clean up, flip the turn table over (felt side down) and place on a clean, flat surface for 15 - 30 minutes or according to your glue's curing time.
